author: Iwan Morgan
message_content: I’ve been recording in this place over the last few days. One of the best experiences i’ve had in the studio. It’s an interesting space designed by the people behind Rockfield back in the 70s when Welsh language records were regularly selling 30-40,000 records (only around 250,000 welsh speakers!).

message_content:
Drums at my favourite live room yesterday, covering a range of sonics across 5 songs - from close and tight to explosive and yuuuge.

Two sets of rooms we could open up track dependent, stereo overhead (4011) + 2 mono overhead options (RCA77dx and EV635a), plus God mic above, and contact mic on hiha

author: cian riordan
message_content: Welcome! First thing I’d suggest is pulling off the front panel if you haven’t already. It’ll give a much more direct, clear sound and will help you better visualize where you’re putting the mics. Those KM84s are going to sound wonderful… would be hard to argue for a better pair of mics on upright.

author: Calvin Lauber
message_content: They way I learned at ardent/royal in Memphis is to choose a corner of the Leslie and mic it so you’re forming a 90 degree angle, makes for a pretty cool stereo image as the horn turns the corner.

author: cian riordan

We leaned mostly on the 251 and found that having it a little below the body of the mandolin pointing up slightly helped w

author: Ross Fortune
message_content:
Doing vocals in a bedroom - basically a parallel box. The walls are padded and those curtains are heavy so it’s very dead. No high / mid problems, but there are some resonances around 100-500Hz. 

I’ve placed the mics where they were least apparent as I walked around singing, but I’m still hearing s

author: Adam Thein
message_content: Heads up the mixer actually only operates at 32 bit when committing by default - if you want to monitor 32bit you have to turn off "Noise Burst Peak Protection" under Preferences -> Processing -> Misc

author: Josh Bowman
message_content:
Interesting I’ve never actually read up on that before! 

Included the avid doc for clarity. seems like you should only worry about this if you need more than 20dbfs of headroom above 0 in your pt mixer. Personally I’d leave it on, saved me quite a few times of blasting myself with a feedback loop…

author: Mike Tierney
message_content: After deliberating with a few other engineer friends, here are the options I tried on hurdy gurdy. author: Brian Reynolds
message_content: I have a mix bus I build thru from second one. The Mass Pass is used for filtering the top and bottom of the mix. On the top of the mix, this move came Castelli. He and Matt go over it on one of the pods. Filter down to 27k with like 8db shelf boost at 16k. Jon at the time would do it on his DW Fern

author: Gabriel Tyranny
message_content:
Using this as a preset has been a great starting point for recording my vocals (tenor male) - Input/Output adjustments based on desired texture, and input/ratio tweaks for balancing texture and compression.

Any notes on tweaks to consider throughout different vocal takes?

author: Edward Rivera
message_content: About yay high

author: Johnny I
message_content: If the register being played on the piano is isolated to the lower end (within the red rectangle), would it be good practice to have the 2 mics covering this range only to get a more balanced L-R image (i.e. 1/3 of of the way in from the edges of the red)?

author: ltucunduva
message_content: thats cool too, you get a more focused image of the drums. i like to lower the front/top mic in order to get a little more from the tom and get more distance from the hihat.

author: Will H
message_content:
Hey all! I did a modern jazz ballad recording session last night and got some sick as sounds and wanted to share some of the set up!!

I tried a Glyn John’s drum OH set up as an experiment though which didn’t go so well haha but thank goodness for MK2 Cymbal mics!

Obviously it could be just what worked for this scenario capturing an performance but its generally something I never consider. Id imagine for modern pop or similar its too dark but maybe i

author: SoundsLikeJoe
message_content: I added a permanent room mic to the ceiling.  It's a mono omni in center and about 2" from the tiles. Has a great crunchy bleed sound. Not hi-fi but for a lot of stuff ...  it's a really nice glue to blend in.

author: Sei046
message_content: Cheers! It can be a bit like being in a pool table at times. That’s actually a better pic of the live room and the other one is the control room before I filled it with stuff and ceiling treatment!
